This conflict has been going on for a little over one month.  It has become a war of attrition.  As in all conflicts of this type, it will take time to define a winner.  In the interim, more people will die and more infrastructure will be destroyed.

You can prepare bacon in the microwave. Just put the strips in a single layer, in a large casserole dish, with a couple of layers of paper towels draped over the top of the dish. Microwave a full power for 2-3 minutes (depending upon your microwave's wattage), then in one minute intervals until done to your liking. I prepare one package at a time, storing the extra cooked bacon in the fridge for quick reheating in the microwave, so that I have to clean the casserole dish only once.

That makes no sense. How could they make more money keeping the property vacant? The rent payed on a property that's vacant is zero. If the property stayed vacant for any length of time the owner would go bankrupt. If the owner then found a tenant that wanted to rent at a high price, well then the high price was really the market rent. All transactions have a buyer and a seller. In the absence of government coercion they establish a price that is mutually beneficial.

Hard to believe, but this actually has been happening all over USA due to low mortgage rates. Landlords can make more money borrowing against artificially inflated property values, even if they are vacant, since commercial appraisals of vacant property is based on the average rental pricing of nearby non-vacant property. If the Landlord lowers the rent to find a Tenant, not only does his appraisal start going down, so do the appraisals for his neighboring Landlords, so no one wants to lower the rent and would rather leave the property vacant. 

Obviously part of the problem is the way vacant property is appraised. But the main problem is low interest rates.

James, I am saying a few things here.
  1. We all tend to think in terms of "offense" when we talk of returns, stocks, ETFs, bonds, etc.
  2. I am suggesting we need to think, much, much more, about declines... severe market declines that can just devastate individuals and families, both financially and emotionally. Really try hard to ask yourself how you will feel, and what you will do when your portfolio is down 40% or 50%! It is almost unthinkable. This is not a fantasy. It has happened, many times, and will happen again. (Read "The Misbehavior of Markets")
  3. Of course timing doesn't work. A very few get lucky with it, but many get killed.
  4. Importantly, what is missing from almost all portfolios, those put together by Financial Advisors, and those put together by people on their own... is a "defensive" strategy. You need investments that are designed to go UP, when markets go down. Ideally, you want "convexity" in these investments; the more the markets go down, the higher your return in these defensive investments.

We've generally stuck to a series of low cost index mutual funds, heavy on the stock side, and kept enough cash around to fund emergencies or life events we could foresee happening in the next couple of years (son's wedding in 8 months, need to replace a car sometime in the next two years, etc.)  To this day, I've not been able to understand why I'd pay something like 1% per year for something that is relatively easy to do myself. Cybersecurity is the one thing that keeps me up as the night as an IT executive responsible for information technology for a large company. The author has some great tips and I want to reinforce her point NEVER to share passwords across multiple accounts. There are a number of excellent password managers and some of them are free for basic services....I recommend LastPass and 1Password. 

More than 90% of successful hacks are a result of phishing attempts sent via email. Never click on a link from an untrusted source which may directly infect your device or take you to a malicious website. Also, never enter sensitive information (e.g. SSN, driver's license, DOB, etc.) unless visiting a trusted site at your initiation (i.e. logging into the IRS to pay your tax bill) and make sure you verify the site's SSL certificate which you can do by hovering over it with your mouse.

I know cybersecurity sounds daunting, but most hackers are not particularly sophisticated. They take advantage of people being lazy who reuse easy to guess passwords, don't keep their operating systems up to date, etc.

Make a habit of practicing safe computing!

I'm a Certified Financial Planner. 
Reading some of these comments, I had to laugh: commenters insisting that life insurance is a bad investment. 
It's not a bad investment or a good one. It's not an investment.
It's insurance. 
Believe it or not I have to explain that to CPA's and tax lawyers. In 1992, Hurricane Andrew demolished my home in Miami. Andrew did about $140,000 worth of damage. I had moved in two years previously and paid about $3,000 total in homeowner's insurance premiums. Allstate paid me $140,000. (I'm simplifying.) What was my profit?
"Ah," I get told, "your profit was $140,000 less the $3,000 you paid for the coverage. Net profit: $137,000."
Yes, CPA's tell me that. They overlook the $140,000 loss. In fact I had no profit but a loss of $3,000, the cost of two years' coverage.
You buy insurance to compensate yourself or a beneficiary for a financial loss. 
If you buy insurance with the idea of making a profit, either you're planning a crime or you don't understand what insurance is, including life insurance.
It's not an investment. You buy it to get compensated (or to compensate your beneficiary) for a loss that will take years to make up, or that can never be made up.
BTW there are essentially two reasons why people buy life insurance: 1) they love someone; 2) out of a sense of financial responsibility, for example to fund a buysell agreement in a business.
I might add that term insurance has its uses but so does permanent. Talk to a financial planner.

As Americans we are generally over insured compared to the rest of the world, but term life insurance is one of the best values around in the right circumstances.  Take away the more useless insurance (pet, legal, extended warranties, etc.) and the premium savings can almost pay the term insurance.

I was 46 at the time of purchase.  After it expired, I did not purchase another one even though I have 7 kids ad a wife because all of the kids were out of HS and some college and my wife is able bodied and can work just fine if she needs to, never mind the fact that we have a pretty solid net worth that eliminates the need for a policy.
Life insurance is a risk mitigation strategy, and if there is no risk, it doesn't need to be employed.  Take that $ and invest it.

I'm retired now and it has been a while since I looked at a life insurance policy.  However, I think there were term policies, which could be renewed at the standard rates on the renewal date even if the health off the insured had declined during the initial term period.  The premiums were higher, but I don't remember them being "astronomically higher."  In other words, the health rating would be the same (i.e. the standard rate), but the premium would be higher due to the increased risk of death associated with an older insured.

If you buy a one year term life policy, there is no guarantee it will be renewed if your health changes in year two or that the premiums will not increase. If you buy a 30 year term life, you get to keep it, with the same premiums for 30 years, although the premiums will be higher than the one year term policy. With a whole life policy, during the early years, while the policy holder is young, a large proportion of the premium goes into savings and a small portion pays for the life insurance. While life insurance has a place in household risk management, those policies themselves carry uncertainty -- uncertainty regarding one's ability to keep the policy until death, uncertainty regarding the final payout (insurance companies do go bankrupt from time to time), uncertainty regarding the value of dollars ultimately paid out and uncertainty regarding beneficiaries' ability to manage the money well enough to meet risk management goals.  On the cost side, there is a large opportunity cost - what regular and prudent investments might yield over a lifetime of monthly additions to one's portfolio.  These are all things worth considering.

If an insurance company goes bankrupt, the other insurers within that state are required to cover the first $250,000 of life insurance for consumers.  As long as you limit the exposure to each insurer to under $250,000, life insurance is pretty safe.

I would bet you don't live in Louisiana, and that you may not know that state laws are not harmonized on this issue.  I'll grant that it's unlikely that any policy will be re-valued to zero, but re-valuations have happened in the past.

A side-note:  some employer-sponsored group term life plans will allow you to "opt-in" for an additional death benefit amount beyond the minimum given to all employees, with cost for the added life coverage paid by the employee. Some insurers may not even require a medical exam or evidence of good health if you bump up your coverage - at least up to a certain maximum amount. 

The downside is that group term life coverage is not a policy that you own and control, but rather a certificate of group insurance, where the employer and the insurance company typically control the terms and conditions of coverage. You generally can't take it with you when you leave, get laid off or retire.  Still, if prior a health issue prevents you from buying your own life policy, it's an option worth exploring with your H.R. benefits representative.
Many employer plans had the option ov converting to a PERSONAL policy without a medical exam etc. But may be this is not the current case.

This goes back to Kinsey's 1948 book. I'm gay but honest about all of it, including (and especially, given my arithmetic-heavy personal background), and can shed some light on some of what you wrote. See, it's a big deal with me: "Thou shalt not mess around with the numbers."

Kinsey wrote that one in eight males (12-1/2%) consider themselves primarily homosexual for at least three years of their lives, usually when they are young. 4% are lifelong homosexual. He wrote that these proportions are half for women, yielding the 3% you cited. Do the numbers for that 3-year group, and it comes out to  9-3/8%. 

In the 1970s, the activists rounded it up to 10%, i.e. 1 in 10. I have no problem with the rounding itself given that the underling numbers themselves can only be seen as educated guesses. The problem is that 10% is too high. Kinsey wrote that two-thirds of the "three-year" group wind up being heterosexual in adulthood. 

Kinsey's methods and scholarship have been attacked, with some justification, but that 3% number has stood the test of time. To the extent that any surveys are accurate, there's a lot of support for it. Maybe it's a bit higher than 3%, but I don't think by much. 

And yeah, I think a lot of people overestimate the proportion. To be fair, I have never seen or heard anyone in the media go higher than 10%. Maybe it's happened and I'm not aware of it. If I had seen or heard of it, I am such a numbers nerd that I'd almost certainly remember it.

Important to note:
"Unlike the Roman Catholic Church, led by the pope, the Orthodox Church doesn’t have a single global leader and has evolved into different independent national churches, resulting in Serbian, Ukrainian, Russian and Bulgarian Orthodox churches"

The Orthodox Christian Churches are recognized as 14 independent churches, generally organized along national lines (Serbia, Albania, Russia, etc). Unlike the Roman Catholic Church, the bishops and  laity may have a  role in selecting their own leadership. Depending on where the church is located, the government may have the right to reject candidates for bishop or Patriarch.  Russia and Turkey are examples of this review process.

While the Patriarch of Constantinople is viewed as the leader of the Orthodox Churches, that role is more of a first among equals than a boss. When the Orthodox Church chooses to speak as a whole, each  national leader signs off on the response.

• Just FYI:

  • Among U.S. states, PA has the 2nd largest concentration of Ukrainian-Americans, ( at 122,000) with only NYS having more. ( CA is 3rd.) Overall, there are about 1M Americans of Ukrainian descent in the USA.
  • The Pittsburgh area has seen four waves of immigration from Ukraine. The first was from 1880-1914. Those immigrants sought out jobs in the local mines and steel mills .Others arrived in the 1920s, 1950s and from 1991 (following the fall of the Soviet Union ) to the present day. Many who arrived in the years right after 1991 were Jewish or Protestant.
  • In 1950, a Ukrainian radio program began as a service to immigrants in the Pittsburgh area. The program still airs Sundays on WPIT. In 1963, the Pittsburgh-based Poltava Ukrainian Dance Company was founded to preserve Ukrainian musical and dance culture in the area. The troupe has performed throughout the country and annually at the Pittsburgh Folk Festival..
  • The Ukrainian Community of Western Pennsylvania, a nonprofit, was formed in 2009 to keep the Ukrainian culture alive. Furthering that goal, St. Mary's Ukrainian Orthodox church in McKees Rocks has hosted Pittsburgh's largest Ukrainian festival for more than a decade every July.

My wife and I, married 51 years, have never had an official budget.  What we have always done is to carefully evaluate expenses as to whether they are 'needs' or 'wants'. Borrowing money is a way of spending your future before it arrives.  A home mortgage is the only thing we have found worthwhile to borrow money for.  Our current home was built using cash. 
Being a 'do it yourselfer' is a valuable trait.  You get good exercise and learn new skills.

My rule is somewhat similar to yours, but scaled to income:  Figure your budget, then add 10%.  So if your budget is $50K, then your $5000 per year is about right.  If your budget is closer to $100K, then you should plan on closer to $10K per year extra.  It makes good intuitive sense that one's extraneous expenses will scale to income so a percentage is more logical than a fixed dollar amount.

Events, Covid and Russia’s war on Ukraine, teaches us that nothing protects anyone from change.  Risk is ever present, with real costs.  We ignore those costs at our peril.  We can however buy insurance.  In this case we can secure our transportation corridors.  We lived in decades of relative world peace and assumed that all risks associated with all transportation everywhere in the world were minimal and equal.  As with many assumptions, we were wrong.

Rational actors will make new assumptions alone with appropriate adjustments when considering sources for commercial business.  Reliability has become the prime virtue.  Businesses will shorten up their supply lines to secure reliability.  A NATO membership card will give those countries that economic advantage.  Without reliable suppliers the cost of transportation is astronomical.

We stand at a nexus in history where roads lead both back to a time dominated by territorial imperialism or forward to a future where nations are interdependent with each other and territorial boundaries no longer define the limits of our markets.  The past, despite its conflicts and suffering, offers ready answers to many of our problems, and anchors many of our core beliefs; while  living in a future dominated by globalization we risk a diminish national identity and right of self determination—Individual achievement will takes a backseat to collaboration, and the one-size-fits-all mantra of ‘economies of scale’ thinking will defer to the diversity of global and cultural needs. 

 The past offers us more of the same: economic inefficiencies, inequality of opportunities, a self-centered mindset, and endless global conflicts. The future offers only one thing—the opportunity to become more than who we are now, both as a community of peoples and as human beings.

It takes good parents, two of them: A strict and providing father, a virtuous, loving mother ⏤From an American culture that taught not entitlement, But gratitude and virtue as American children growing up where there was a consequence for every behavior in a civilized society governed by fair play and the rule of law, not by men. ⏤Families that embrace with reverence, pride, and conviction our American Providence like no other ever. There exists no substitute. None. Not a village or government bureaucracy that does not, never has, cannot, and never will. It’s easy to lay blame when we need look in the mirror. Since the 1970s, increasingly more have found it easier to drug our kids than take the time necessary to be good parents to our children. Not to be their best friends. Not to cosset and mollycoddle but to show by instruction and by example right from wrong, behavior and consequence. ⏤Discipline as our grandparents did without drugs. No future with failed individual parenting conferred on the collective.

This is very interesting to me because I grew up as an extremely slow reader with low comprehension. I struggled thru grade school, high school and college. Then, I was introduced to audio books. Listening to books changed my life. Suddenly I enjoyed books and had a higher comprehension of what I had just heard. I would guess I have averaged at least one audio book per week for the past thirty-three years. 
This article indicates to me that this is the same old problem...even if it is in a different format.
